snippet.textDisplay: To the people in the comments joining the Twitter conspiracy theorists and claiming that China's lying about their numbers: if the rate of infection was truly higher, it would be IMPOSSIBLE to cover up.  With China's population size and density, the numbers many of you and the far-right anti-China conspiracy theorists are claiming would statistically mean MILLIONS of deaths. Hospitals all over China would be full and people would be dying on the streets. No matter how much you've bought in to China being some kind of cartoonishly evil villain, a cover up of that scale in the modern age is impossible, and all the real evidence shows that the crisis in Hubei is over because of quick and decisive action against the virus.
snippet.textOriginal: To the people in the comments joining the Twitter conspiracy theorists and claiming that China's lying about their numbers: if the rate of infection was truly higher, it would be IMPOSSIBLE to cover up. snippet.textDisplay:
If there's one thing this Wuhan SARS virus (which is what the Loyal Chinese lapdog WHO called COVID-19 after China's political lobbying) taught us, it must be the fact that the China government is a habitual lair. In short - their case figures are not reliable.
Hit the emergency button like China? It shows that you know China nowhere as well as those in Hong Kong and Taiwan. No offence, seeing and making sense of the figure and graphs is one thing, taking active measures are quite another, and here is the key point - Hongkongers and Taiwanese, both closest to China geographically and commercially were supposed to be most affected, and yet they were far better than the Europeans and Americans, because both do the same thing --> wear surgical masks whenever you are among the crowd and do not trust China. The case figures in HK and TW will show you whether this is true.
Washing hands are necessary, but for WHO to stress this is no different from making a statement of discovering that your mother is a woman. WEAR THE MASKS!
snippet.textOriginal:
If there's one thing this Wuhan SARS virus (which is what the Loyal Chinese lapdog WHO called COVID-19 after China's political lobbying) taught us, it must be the fact that the China government is a habitual lair. In short - their case figures are not reliable.
Hit the emergency button like China? It shows that you know China nowhere as well as those in Hong Kong and Taiwan. No offence, seeing and making sense of the figure and graphs is one thing, taking active measures are quite another, and here is the key point - Hongkongers and Taiwanese, both closest to China geographically and commercially were supposed to be most affected, and yet they were far better than the Europeans and Americans, because both do the same thing --> wear surgical masks whenever you are among the crowd and do not trust China. The case figures in HK and TW will show you whether this is true.
Washing hands are necessary, but for WHO to stress this is no different from making a statement of discovering that your mother is a woman. WEAR THE MASKS!

snippet.textDisplay:
I'm no mathemagician so I don't get why using logarithmic is that useful in showing the public new cases or deaths etc. I get that it can help show detail in a graph that has all countries in but it also makes the public think that the curve is flattening out because it naturally flattens out as the higher numbers compress. The UK government are showing logarithmic scale graphs in their daily briefings rather than linear which to me is problematic as it makes it look like they are dealing with the problem better than they are, particularly when most of the people watching it have never even heard the word "logarithmic" before and are constantly being drilled with the idea that to win we must "flatten the curve" (so when they see a curve flattening out they automatically assume there are less new cases).

Great video though - helped me understand why some of this can be useful :)
snippet.textOriginal:
I'm no mathemagician so I don't get why using logarithmic is that useful in showing the public new cases or deaths etc.  I get that it can help show detail in a graph that has all countries in but it also makes the public think that the curve is flattening out because it naturally flattens out as the higher numbers compress. The UK government are showing logarithmic scale graphs in their daily briefings rather than linear which to me is problematic as it makes it look like they are dealing with the problem better than they are, particularly when most of the people watching it have never even heard the word "logarithmic" before and are constantly being drilled with the idea that to win we must "flatten the curve" (so when they see a curve flattening out they automatically assume there are less new cases).

Great video though - helped me understand why some of this can be useful :)

snippet.textDisplay:
As the DailyWire reported on the 28th, there are plenty of reasons to doubt these numbers out of China and a real case to throw them out entirely:
British Scientific Advisers Claim China’s Outbreak Could Be ‘15 To 40 Times’ Worse Than Reported, Report Says
https://www.dailywire.com/news/british-scientific-advisers-claim-chinas-outbreak-could-be-15-to-40-times-worse-than-reported-report-says

In the article, they cite the Daily Mail for the main statistic but they also cite the:

Washington Post who cautions these numbers, "China is reporting big successes in the coronavirus fight. Should we trust the numbers?"

The New York Times, who wrote an article where China admits to underreporting their SARS numbers.
https://www.nytimes.com/2003/04/21/world/the-sars-epidemic-epidemic-china-admits-underreporting-its-sars-cases.html

and Bloomberg News where there are reports of massive lines at funeral homes in China for people to get their loved ones cremated:
https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-03-27/stacks-of-urns-in-wuhan-prompt-new-questions-of-virus-s-toll

snippet.textDisplay: Yes, exponential growth is hardly covered by the media at all. I saw an article by a Dr. explaining why it's so important to consider. No wonder exponential growth is too much for our tiny brains.

snippet.textDisplay: I just watched this video because I couldn't see from the thumbnail what was being plotted on each axis (other than that is was exponential).  One thing that is interesting to me is that it doesn't take into consideration any "resets".  For example, let's say that a country falls off the line, i.e. gets things under control, then another outbreak occurs.  You can see this happen in the animation with China when it bounces up and down after if falls off the line.  Shouldn't that be treated as a new animation starting over again at zero?
snippet.textOriginal: I just watched this video because I couldn't see from the thumbnail what was being plotted on each axis (other than that is was exponential).  One thing that is interesting to me is that it doesn't take into consideration any "resets".  For example, let's say that a country falls off the line, i.e. gets things under control, then another outbreak occurs.  You can see this happen in the animation with China when it bounces up and down after if falls off the line.  Shouldn't that be treated as a new animation starting over again at zero?

snippet.textDisplay: My question is: how would the above graph look if instead of numbers of cases, the number of cases relative to the total population of a region were used as the dependent variable? In some small countries, 10k cases would be more than 1% of the entire population, whereas in the US, it would be around 0.003% of the total population. It seems to me that in a larger country, there would likely be several independent centers of contagion, each with its own start date and rate of growth, but the figures for that country would be their sum—would this distort the exponentiality of the growth curve? Also, the upper limit on growth would obviously be quite different in, say, Iceland versus the US.
snippet.textOriginal: My question is: how would the above graph look if instead of numbers of cases, the number of cases relative to the total population of a region were used as the dependent variable? In some small countries, 10k cases would be more than 1% of the entire population, whereas in the US, it would be around 0.003% of the total population. It seems to me that in a larger country, there would likely be several independent centers of contagion, each with its own start date and rate of growth, but the figures for that country would be their sum—would this distort the exponentiality of the growth curve? Also, the upper limit on growth would obviously be quite different in, say, Iceland versus the US.

snippet.textDisplay:
There's one thing that's often forgotten.

It's that just because a country might have the situation under control now, doesn't mean that the virus won't come back. And that will be the problem. These measures are so strict, keeping the measures for many months, maybe several years, while hoping for a vaccine might be more damaging than the virus itself in the long run. Even though it looks like China is getting control, it doesn't mean a second, third, even forth wave won't come. So how long is China willing to keep their country shut down and keep entire provinces under constant curfews? Some say a vaccine might be two years away, other say it's possible that we might never find a vaccine.

So the second a country ease up their protective measures, the virus will come back. And you'll have the whole situation again.

And another thing often not talked about is the mutations this virus is doing. A week ago Iceland found 40 different mutations of the virus, in a relative small number of infected. Viruses like these are programmed to make mutations, in order to survive when people develop immunity. This is probably what happened with the Spanish flu, as most peolpe who died from the Spanish flu died about one year in, during two big waves. These new waves was most likely caused by mutations, making the virus more deadly. Then, out of no-where, all of a sudden - the deaths stopped. No-one at the time knew why, but now we understand it was probably because a new mutation of the virus was defeating the other mutation; and this new mutation just happened to not be as deadly.

So, we might have mutations making this virus far worse than it is now causing new waves, or we might also have new mutations making this virus less dangerous.

The projection graphs like these are showing, shows the current situation - but we know of experience with viruses that they come in waves. So seeing numbers go down might just be a false sense of security. We're just seeing the first wave go down, we don't know how many waves there's gonna be. There might just be one wave, or there might be five waves.

Some say a vaccine might be two years away, other say it's possible that we might never find a vaccine.

So the second a country ease up their protective measures, the virus will come back. And you'll have the whole situation again.

And another thing often not talked about is the mutations this virus is doing. A week ago Iceland found 40 different mutations of the virus, in a relative small number of infected. Viruses like these are programmed to make mutations, in order to survive when people develop immunity. This is probably what happened with the Spanish flu, as most peolpe who died from the Spanish flu died about one year in, during two big waves. These new waves was most likely caused by mutations, making the virus more deadly. Then, out of no-where, all of a sudden - the deaths stopped. No-one at the time knew why, but now we understand it was probably because a new mutation of the virus was defeating the other mutation; and this new mutation just happened to not be as deadly.

So, we might have mutations making this virus far worse than it is now causing new waves, or we might also have new mutations making this virus less dangerous.

The projection graphs like these are showing, shows the current situation - but we know of experience with viruses that they come in waves. So seeing numbers go down might just be a false sense of security. We're just seeing the first wave go down, we don't know how many waves there's gonna be. snippet.textDisplay:
Nice video. What about plotting deaths instead of cases?

Cases depend a lot on tests done by each country and this can change significantly. Also, when a country starts to perform more tests could seem that cases are increasing but actually you are confirming cases that already existed before (stock). I am from Spain and here looks like we have around 10 times more cases than confirmed ones and it is probably the same all around the globe.

Deaths are much easier to confirm and count even if counting methods change even within Europe where some countries count only deaths at the hospital (France) or some don't count deaths with previous pathologies (Germany).
snippet.textOriginal:

snippet.textDisplay:
Love how Denmark, Sweden and Norway, each do a little dip in the chart, diverging from the rest...but then continue upward.
Being from Denmark myself, I can confirm how there was a public announcement, causing a bit of a scare, that led to an initial panic, followed by a period of nation-wide isolation (as desired). Shopping was SUCH a delight in this time. You'd go into a store and there'd be 2~3 other people, allowing me to get my shopping done in seconds.
However, now that a few weeks have passed, people got "used to" or I might even say... "BORED" of the Covid-19 spread and loosened up way too much... Now that I go shopping, the stores a crammed as usual. Old folks, who are ill advised to be leaving the safety of their homes in these times, pushing carts around at 1 meter per minute. Couples, bringing ALL their kids, to clog up the candy, or dairy-isle, to bicker over what flavor yogurt to get and whatnot... That's likely why, the growth has picked up again, in Scandinavia.
People got way too relaxed, way too soon, all at the same time, to continue as they've always had and thus, the spread picks up the pace again. 😷

Shopping was SUCH a delight in this time. You'd go into a store and there'd be 2~3 other people, allowing me to get my shopping done in seconds.
However, now that a few weeks have passed, people got _"used to"_ or I might even say... _"BORED"_ of the Covid-19 spread and loosened up way too much... Now that I go shopping, the stores a crammed as usual. Old folks, who are ill advised to be leaving the safety of their homes in these times, pushing carts around at 1 meter per minute. snippet.textDisplay: Can people just stay inside and protest against the government even if we have to work or go to schools. Thank you and take care of yourself.

snippet.textDisplay:
When there is a potential global threat it’s clear that every nation should assist the nation that is initially suffering or struggling.
Let’s look at the global response to this pandemic.
When China was fighting the viral infection and its spread the West was totally disinterested. Same with Iran. It was only when Italy had a spike of deaths due to its health system being overloaded that attention in the media commenced - and more importantly a pandemic declared by the WHO.
It would be like a large meteor heading towards say Japan and the world not assisting Japan because it’s not their nation that will be destroyed or being affected. The meteor then knocks out Japan and the resultant tsunami kills ten times more people all over the planet.
This is a human threat.
The embarrassing thing for the West was that little Cuba sent 53 doctors to Italy and China sent a medical team and equipment to Italy as well. How many doctors did other countries send? Including from the US UK and Europe?
Shameful but alas predictable
snippet.textOriginal:
When there is a potential global threat it’s clear that every nation should assist the nation that is initially suffering or struggling.
Let’s look at the global response to this pandemic.
When China was fighting the viral infection and its spread the West was totally disinterested. Same with Iran. It was only when Italy had a spike of deaths due to its health system being overloaded that attention in the media commenced - and more importantly a pandemic declared by the WHO.
It would be like a large meteor heading towards say Japan and the world not assisting Japan because it’s not their nation that will be destroyed or being affected. The meteor then knocks out Japan and the resultant tsunami kills ten times more people all over the planet.
This is a human threat. 
The embarrassing thing for the West was that little Cuba sent 53 doctors to Italy and China sent a medical team and equipment to Italy as well. How many doctors did other countries send? Including from the US UK and Europe? 
Shameful but alas predictable
